basex.home:
BaseX is a native XML database.
It features compact storage structures, efficient XPath and XQuery implementations and a visual frontend, facilitating visual access to the stored data. BaseX is written in Java and freely available for download. It is developed by the Database and Information Systems Group at the University of Konstanz.

news.news-item: This web site is now completely generated via BaseX and XQuery. The next release is scheduled for February.

documentation.section:
BaseX comes as an executable .jar (Java Archive), which automatically determines the correct system settings (i.e. paths and environment variables). Java 5 or later is needed to run BaseX.
By default, the graphical interface of BaseX is launched. To manually start BaseX you have (at least) the following options:
Start the GUI, granting more memory to the virtual machine:
java -Xmx512m -jar BaseX.jar
Start the console version:
java -cp BaseX.jar org.basex.BaseX
Typing help at the command prompt gives you a list of the available database commands.
Have a look into the FAQ to get more info on BaseX.

ul.li: Two examples for XPath and XQuery might help you to integrate BaseX in your own project
You can also browse the JavaDocs of the source code
We will soon support the XQuery API

commands.text: Here you find the BaseX commands which you can enter in the console mode or in the Command text field in the GUI:

command.name: Help
command.desc: Get help on BaseX commands. If [command] is specified, information on the specific command is printed; otherwise, all commands are listed. If 'all' is specified, hidden commands are included.

command.name: Create
command.desc:
Create a database from XML or the filesystem, or create an index:
xml [file]
Create a new database for the the XML document specified with [file].
The database will be named after the document name, excluding the suffix.
fs [database] [path]
Create a database for the specified file [path].
The Database will be named [database].
index [text|attribute|word|fulltext]
Create the specified index for the currently opened database.

command.name: Info
command.desc:
Show information on the currently opened database:
no argument
show global information
database
show database information
index
show information on the existing indexes.
table [start end | query]
show the internal XML table representation for the specified numeric range [start-end], or for the results of the specified [query]

command.name: Drop
command.desc:
Drop a database or an index:
database [name]
Drop the database specified with [name].
index [text|attribute|word|fulltext]
Drop the specified index in the currently opened database.

command.name: Export
command.desc: Export the current database or node set to an XML document, named [file].

command.name: XPath
command.desc: Perform the specified XPath 1.0 [query] and print its result.

command.name: XQuery
command.desc: Perform the specified XQuery 1.0 [query] and print its result. The complete input is treated as XQuery, so no other commands are allowed in the same line. If no query is specified after the command, the query is created from the following inputs, finished by an empty.

command.name: Find
command.desc:
Evaluate a simple keyword [query] and print its results. This command is used in the simple search mode in the GUI. The following prefixes are supported:
(none): find any tags and substrings
= find exact text nodes
@ find attributes and attribute values
@= find exact attribute values

command.name: CD
command.desc: Evaluate the [query] as XPath 1.0 and set the result as new context set.

command.name: Copy
command.desc: Copy database nodes. Evaluate the XPath 1.0 [source] query and insert the resulting nodes as child nodes into the [target] query. [pos] specifies the child position; if 0 is specified, the nodes are inserted as last child. The queries should be enclosed by brackets.

command.name: Delete
command.desc: Delete database nodes resulting from the specified [target] query. The query should be enclosed by brackets.

command.name: Insert
command.desc:
Insert database nodes. Insert a fragment or a specific node at the specified child [pos] of the specified [target] query:
element [name] [pos] [target]
Insert an element with the specified tag [name].
text [text] [pos] [target]
Insert a text node with the specified [text].
attribute [name] [value] [target]
Insert an attribute with the specified [name] and [value]
comment [text] [pos] [target]
Insert a comment with the specified [text].
pi [name] [value] [pos] [target]
Insert a processing instruction with the specified [name] and [value].
fragment [frag] [pos] [target]
Insert an XML [frag].

command.name: Update
command.desc:
Update database nodes satisfying the specified [target] query.
element [name] [target]
Update the resulting elements with the specified tag [name].
text [text] [target]
Update the resulting text nodes with the specified [text].
attribute [name] [value] [target]
Update the resulting attributes with the specified [name] and [value].
comment [text] [target]
Update the resulting comments with the specified [text].
pi [name] [value] [target]
Update the resulting processing instructions with the specified [name] and [value].

command.name: Set
command.desc:
Sets global options. The currently set values can be shown with the info command. The following [option]s are available and can be turned [on] or [off]:
debug
Show internal debug info.
mainmem
Use main-memory mode.
The following commands apply to the creation of new databases:
chop
Chop all XML whitespace nodes.
entity
Parse XML entities.
textindex
Index text nodes.
attrindex
Index attribute values.
wordindex
Index all words (simplified full-text)
ftindex
Index full-text
dbpath [path]: Set a new database [path]
The following commands apply to querying:
info [all]
Show (all) info on query evaluation.
serialize
Turn serialization of query results on/off.
xmloutput
Serialize query results as XML.
runs [nr]
Set the number of query runs.
Have a look into the FAQ to find more information on the available options.

command.name: Exit
command.desc: Leave the console mode of BaseX.

entry.question: What is BaseX?
entry.answer: BaseX is a native XML database. It features an XPath/XQuery implementation, supports updates and has a visual frontend, facilitating visual access to the stored data.

entry.question: On what systems does BaseX run?
entry.answer: BaseX is completely written in Java. As such it is plattform-independant and should run on any plattform that has a Java Virtual Machine available. BaseX uses Java Version 1.5 or later, so this might be a limitation. BaseX has been tested on Windows (2000, XP, Vista), Max OS X (10.4, 10.5), Linux(SuSE xxx, Debian) and OpenBSD (4.2).

entry.question: Who maintains BaseX?
entry.answer: BaseX is developed by the Database and Information Systems Group at the University of Konstanz. Main developer and project leader is Christian Grün. Several students and other group members have contributed to the project.

entry.question: Where to get the latest version?

entry.question: Is there access to the source code?

The BaseX sources are available in a Subversion repository via Sourceforge:
Sourceforge Project Site

entry.question: How can I help/contribute?
entry.answer: BaseX is still work in progress. So we are definitely interested in all kind of experiences you gain during usage. Please provide feedback, bug reports, report about missing features, your application domain. This all can be done by posting to info@basex.org.

entry.question: I found a bug, how do I file bug report?
entry.answer: There is a bug reporting system on SourceForge. Feel free to send an email to info@basex.org.

entry.question: How can I launch the console mode of BaseX?
entry.answer:
Just enter java -cp BaseX.jar org.base.BaseX on the command line. The Java option -Xmx... reserve more memory, and the -h flag of BaseX lists all available flags: java -Xmx512m -cp BaseX.jar org.basex.BaseX -h
BaseX 4.0; DBIS, University of Konstanz Usage: BaseX [options] [query] [query] specify query file -c chop whitespaces -d debug mode -e skip entity parsing -o [file] specify output file -p handle query file as XPath -q<cmd> send BaseX commands -v/V show (all) process info -x print result as xml -z skip query output

entry.question: What can I do in the console mode?
entry.answer:
Type in help to get a list of all BaseX commands. Several commands can be separated by semicolons. To evaluate commands without entering the console mode, you can use the -q option on the command line: java -jar BaseX.jar -vq 'create xml input.xml; xpath /' Process Info ON Database created in 195.2 ms. entry.question: What is XPath/XQuery?

ul.li: XPath is a simple query language for finding information in an XML document. XPath is used to navigate through elements and attributes in an XML document (XPath - W3C Website).
XQuery is a complete query language from the W3C that provides an easy way to query, transform, and integrate XML data. (XQuery - W3C Website).

entry.question: What is Whitespace Chopping?
entry.answer: This option removes all whitespaces between tags and contents. In the current version of BaseX, there is no DTD or XML schema detection which would make it possible to explicitly ignore special whitespaces.

entry.question: What is Entity Parsing?
entry.answer: The parsing of entities in the document can be skipped or switched on with this option. Entities are important for DTD declarations and definitions of special characters.

entry.question: How can i display the name of attributes?
entry.answer: There is an option in the Options/Preferences menu where it's possible to choose, replace tags with @name attributes.

entry.question: How many views are there and what do they do?

dl.dd: Executes XPath, XQuery and simple queries to explore the xml document.
Displays information on the compilation and evaluation of an XPath or XQuery request, including some simple profiling.
Displays query results and other textual output.
This visualization represents all data in a TreeMap. All nodes of the XML document are represented as rectangles, filling the complete area.
This visualization displays all XML nodes in a usual tree view.
This visualization displays all XML nodes in a table with rows and columns.
This view provides context sensitive information to use all the BaseX features.

entry.question: A Table View for hierachical data. Sorry, but sounds brain-damaged.
entry.answer:
It sounds brain-damaged but it's really useful for many kinds of data. It's just another visualization which provides an efficient and effective way to display data. See the following example:
It's possible to edit/add/delete elements in the table view directly.

entry.question: What is Realtime Filtering?
entry.answer: If realtime filtering is enabled, all visualizations directly show the query results while entering the query. If this feature is disabled, the query results are highlighted in the visualizations and can be ecplicitly filtered using the 'Filter' button.

entry.question: What does the Filter button exactly do?
entry.answer: After pressing this button, the visualizations display the previously highlighted XML nodes, omitting all the other nodes of the document. If realtime filtering is enabled, the Filter button will be disabled, and all results are automatically filtered.

entry.question: How can I search without XPath/XQuery?
entry.answer:
The Search field triggers a simple search query in the XML document. The following syntax is supported:
QueryDescription
foo Find tags and texts containing foo
=foo Find exact matching text nodes
@foo Find attributes and attribute values
@=foo Find exact attribute values

entry.question: The search field in the query panel and the search field right beyond the buttons, do they differ?
entry.answer: Not really, both offer the same functionality, but in the query panel there is a dropdown menu where it's possible to choose tags or attributes of the XML document.

entry.question: How can I configure the look and feel of BaseX?
entry.answer: All panels are freely adjust- and dragable. Changing of colors, fonts and the layout is possible via the 'Layout' entry in the 'Options' menu.

entry.question: What is the Main-Memory Mode?
entry.answer: The Main-Memory Mode speeds up querying but disables updates. The table data is kept in memory and the text of a document is still accesseed from disk.

entry.question: How can I import my file system? What does that mean?
entry.answer: To import a file system, go to 'File/Import Filesystem...'. You will be prompted for the next steps. A file hierarchy traversal is performed and the directory structure of the filesystem is mapped into an XML representation. Additionally some metadata is extracted from some known file types. What you get is an 'XML view' of your current file system. You can query the filesystem just as any other database instance. Manipulation (update, deletion) of the XML database instance representing a file hierarchy has no effect on the real filesystem.

entry.question: How can I import my data aka how do i create a new database instance aka how to shred an XML file?

ol.li: If your input data is an XML file, you can use the 'New' command. BaseX will create a new database with the name of your XML file. (GUI only)
You can use the Create command. (GUI and console)

entry.question: Where does BaseX store data and configuration files?

ul.li: The databases are stored in a BaseXData directory in your home directory. The path can be changed in the GUI via the Options/Preferences menu.
The two configuration files .basex/.basewin are stored in the same directory. This path can't be changed by the user.

entry.question: How do you measure the performance of the queries?
entry.answer:
The measurements include the compilation, evaluation and printing time of a query. There are different ways to get the performance information:
Console: use '-v' flag as command line argument
Console Mode: enter 'set info' or 'set info all' in the console mode
GUI Mode: display performance results in the QueryInfo view

entry.question: What indexing techniques are available and what do they do?
entry.answer:
Indexes can speedup queries by magnitudes. Currently, four indexes exist:
Text Index: All text nodes are indexed to speedup XPath predicates.
Attribute Value Index: All attributes are indexed to speedup XPath predicates.
Word Index: All terms in text nodes are indexed to speedup word based queries.
Fulltext Index: A full-fledged fulltext index is created to speedup fulltext queries in XPath. Note that the indexes only speedup XPath and simple user queries. Currently, XQuery does not make use of the indexes.

entry.question: Is it possible to start BaseX as a Server?
entry.answer:
In addition to the standalone version, it is possible to run BaseX in a Client/Server environment:
Server To start BaseX in server mode, just type:
java -cp BaseX.jar org.basex.BaseXServer
Client To run a BaseX client, please type:
java -cp BaseX.jar org.basex.BaseXClient -s server.org
The -s flag specifies the computer on which the server is running.
To list all available flags, just add -h to the call, e.g.: java -cp BaseX.jar org.basex.BaseXServer -h
BaseX 4.0; DBIS, University of Konstanz Usage: java BaseXServer [options] stop stop server -d debug mode -h show this help -p<port> specify server port

entry.question: Can I have more information on the XPath/XQuery implementations?
entry.answer: Note that, in BaseX, XPath and XQuery are based on different implementations. Whereas XPath was especially tuned for efficient querying, XQuery strives for a high conformity with the XQuery standard. As soon as our XQuery implementation includes the optimizations that have been applied to XPath, the XPath implementation might get obsolete.

entry.question: OK, you support several Indexes. What exactly can I use and how?
entry.answer:
Text indexes allow a speedup of order of magnitudes for text-based queries. Currently, the indexes are only utilized by XPath queries. For example, the following query will be internally rewritten to access the the text index first:
Text-Based Query /descendant::node[text() = 'findme']

entry.question: Tell me more about XQuery Full-Text. How can I use it?
entry.answer:
The full-text features can be used in XPath as well as in XQuery. Again, queries will be evaluated much faster in XPath, and XQuery covers more features of the language specification. In the following, two simple examples for full-text queries are shown, based on the W3C Sample Document:
XPath Full-Text Return all title tags which contain the word 'Usability':
//title[text() ftcontains 'Usability']
XQuery Full-Text Return all authors, containing 'Marigold': for $i in //author score $s where $i/text() ftcontains 'Marigold' return <hit score='{ $s }'>{ $i/text() }</hit>

entry.question: How do you support XML Updates. Do you accomplish any standard?
entry.answer: BaseX provides internal commands to perform updates on XML (see also BaseX Commands). Moreover, the GUI provides a convenient way to perform updates on the data. Support of the W3C XQuery Update Facility is still on our (extensive) todo list..

inproceedings.title: Melting Pot XML - Bringing File Systems and Databases One Step Closer
inproceedings.abstract: Evaluates the basic idea to regard a file system as semi-structured data and to implement file system operations using XPath/XQuery.

inproceedings.title: Visually Exploring and Querying XML with BaseX
inproceedings.abstract: BaseX offers an intuitive, visual access to semi-structured data. Import your file system and browse it on a treemap or try one of the several others views (zoomable table, file explorer that navigates into the file itself ...) It thus demonstrates the efficiency of the underlying storage.
